Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Democratizing Computer Science Education through a Sustainable Peer Tutoring Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project seeks to create an effective peer-tutoring platform for Computer Science (CS) education. Currently, the software industry in the United States is suffering from a shortage of 100,000 CS professionals per year. The root can be traced to the lack of CS preparation in K-12 education, where the majority of students do not receive proper CS education at school. While there is an ongoing effort to establish CS education in K-12, the teacher training and certification process is slow and expensive. Receiving mentorship is crucial to learning Computer Science. Online solutions that offer one-on-one tutoring are expensive and therefore not affordable by the majority of students. This project offers an affordable solution: a sustainable, global, online peer tutoring community in which every student can learn CS, programming, and STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics)-related content from their peers. By lowering the tutoring costs to a fraction of the price of other existing solutions, majority of students, in particular in underserved communities, will have access to affordable quality CS education. Additionally, with its collaborative nature and social engagement elements, it can prepare students with 21st century skills and broaden participation of women and underrepresented populations in Computer Science.

The goal of this Phase I project is to design, develop, and evaluate distributed communication and coordination software and educational content that are required for effective remote peer tutoring. Using a real-time collaborative game design software, peer tutors work virtually yet closely with students to guide them through the creation of a video game, solve computational problems, write programs together, and answer their questions just-in-time. This project features a distributed, shared development environment that allows multiple users to edit the same project at the same time. This real-time collaboration system employs a fast and scalable technology that manages multi-user concurrent editing of a shared project. The theoretical framework for this project is built based on 1) peer tutoring techniques such as Peer-Led Team Learning, which have been used successfully to teach CS, and to increase the participation of underrepresented groups; 2) decades of research and development in collaborative and social software engineering. In this project, an engaging peer tutoring unit for teaching computer science and STEM concepts in the context of collaborative game design will be produced and implemented in after-school settings in a number of schools to evaluate and establish the educational feasibility of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview
Currently, the software industry in the United States is suffering from a shortage of Computer Science professionals. The root can be traced to the lack of Computer Science preparation in K-12 education. Few K-12 schools offer Computer Science courses and technology teachers do not necessarily have a formal Computer Science and programming background. Thus, the majority of students do not have the opportunity to be exposed to Computer Science at school. Receiving mentorship is crucial to learning Computer Science. While there is an ongoing effort to establish Computer Science education in K-12, the teacher training and certification process is slow and expensive. Moreover, online solutions that offer one-on-one tutoring are expensive and therefore not affordable by the majority of students. Actimator Academy offers an affordable solution: a sustainable peer tutoring community in which every student can learn CS, programming, and STEM-related content from their peers. In Actimator Academy, peer tutoring takes place in the context of game design and using standards-based curriculum and resources. With Actimator Academy peer tutoring community, every middle and high school student will have access to a CS tutor. This Phase I project evaluated the technical and educational feasibility of Actimator Academy.
Technical Outcomes
The technical objective was to create the first incarnation of Actimator Academy to enable tutors to teach CS and STEM topics to remote learners, encompassing the existing Actimator collaborative game design environment and newly developed coordination, communication, and artifact management tools. We improved the core real-time collaboration technology and enhanced software capabilities to better support peer mentoring between remote groups of students. In addition, Actimator achieved the performance required for remote users anywhere in the country to work together and help each other in real time. The prototype developed in Phase I was successfully used by students in a pilot study to validate the educational feasibility of Actimator Academy.
Educational Outcomes
The educational objective was to produce an engaging peer tutoring unit for teaching computer science and STEM concepts in the context of collaborative game design, prepare tutors to deliver it to peers, and implement in an after-school settings in three schools to establish Actimator Academy’s feasibility as an educational tool. During the pilot program, students were engaged and seemed to enjoy the course—the highlight from the student perspective was the ability to design and create their own game. Evidence from content tests and challenges suggests that the platform and Actimator Academy activities support the acquisition of Computer Science content knowledge. Finally, this pilot exposed students to collaborative learning experiences and helped them practice 21st century skills (communication, collaboration, problem solving, leadership). Students who chose to become peer leaders enjoyed stepping into a leadership role, benefited from leadership training and taking on that role, and had a high degree of motivation to continue to engage in Computer Science and leadership. Though more extensive leader training would be helpful, students trained with the process we developed exhibited high ability to lead their peers in game design activities.
